Bioshock Infinite Review  - Text version.

Bioshock Infinite is a welcome addition to the series, but in some ways is less classy than the original Bioshock, and somewhat plays quite differently despite some distinct similarities. What is perhaps most notable about the game is the distinctive looks and overt messages contained within to really place players in a utopian world where there's less horror and more social dysfunction. It's perhaps more deliberately thought provoking, but in some ways the story can be largely ignored due to the heavy focus on large scale combat. In a way, the game feels less personal as a result but still retains a unique edge due to some fantastic artistic direction and well placed and performed audio both in the music and voice over performances.

If you're a fan of first person adventuring, then there's definitely lots to be enjoyed here although the lack of stealth is a bit disappointing as the full on combat can get a little repetitive and predictable at times. However, the game's progressive style certainly lends itself more to those looking for a more action packed adventure which the game doesn't shy away from at all. As a game in its own right, it's big, somewhat clever, and most importantly well worth picking up and playing.

Okay, let me preface this by acknowledging that this game is reasonably well polished, visually impressive and doesn't really contain any content that is particularly offensive.

But otherwise this game is incredibly bad, and I am going to lay out why. 

I think the first thing to do is to comment on the gameplay in comparison with it's forebears, Bioshock and Bioshock 2. This game does not play much like them, yet it plays too much like them. The gameplay was stripped down, with numerous features removed and replaced, and yet no significant work was done to improve the combat. This is a problem because Bioshock combat isn't good, it needs elements to it to give it flavour and strategy, such as hacking, interacting with elements in the environment and making enemies target one another, etc. Infinite only has possession as a function for replacing hacking and mind control but it does this with no flair at all. Hacked turrents/enemies are invincible when they are your ally meaning when the ability runs out you have to deal with them then. The Vigors have almost no narrative reason to be in the game and they lack variety even moreso than the Plasmids from prior games.

The weapons are a massive disappointment. Only allowing for two weapons carried massively cuts down on variety of gameplay yet again, their upgrades are not interesting and just change some stats. And you're penalised for not focusing on upgrading only a couple of weapons that you will use all the time. The gunplay is terrible, enemies are bullet sponges making the combat slow and monotonous. I also think that though some areas of the game are very pretty, much of the game takes place in pretty nondescript corridors, or generic open areas.

Enemies simply spawn in waves or wander around randomly. They never use tactics, there's only a handful of enemy types. The most interesting part of the game is a fairly standard stealth section and the one "boss" fight it has was a massive slog. At no point is this game every truly fun to play for all the obscene amount of money that clearly went into it. 

Having said that, the story and characters are somehow even worse. Elizabeth, for whom much of the game centres on, is a lifeless and annoying character whom it's almost impossible to feel any kind of bond with because once you are meant to protect her... you don't. She doesn't exist as far as the game's enemies are concerned, and thus you do not at any point ever protect her. You simply mass murder your way through Columbia whilst she can randomly spawn ammo, health or money for you. Despite her years of confinement, she acts like a ditzy disney princess for most of the game and when things do get more serious, she has a complete personality turn and becomes a relentless and single minded fool who spouts meaningless philosophical nonsense. The ending is incredibly stupid, makes no logical sense and is intensely cruel and evil. 

In the end this game doesn't manage to be about anything. It has no real message to it, no moral, and no interesting insight into any of it's characters or setting, the setting of Columbia is explored for about an hour at the start and then simply becomes a linear tube for Booker to violently fight through. All of it's characters are stock, reprehensible and pretty much at no point is it possible to sympathise with any of them as they perpetuate a cycle of greed, intolerance and murder. At least in Bioshock Rapture had an ideal built on foundations of intellectualism and free knowledge, Columbia is little more than an idealised floating American city circa 1901. If you're familiar enough with the time period, the game makes very few attempts to use that knowledge for gain, like I've seen in other historical period games like Assassins Creed. 

And above all, it does not serve any of it's narrative aims by being a poor shooter that doesn't even meet the most basic criteria to be a fun game.

The BioShock franchise has abandoned its waterlogged roots to explore a city improbably floating around high in the sky. You (Booker DeWitt) arrive there to track down a girl. You only know you have to take her back down with you to make up for some unspecified debt. The society you encounter is creepily cheerful, full of faith in its leader (The Prophet) and it is rabidly xenophobic. Slavery is still a thing and you get the feeling you have walked into a cult. Gleefully, you realize it is only a matter of time before the whole sick system gets torn to shreds. And in typical BioShock fashion, once it has, you still feel somewhat bad for the bodies you come across everywhere.

BioShock Infinite pulls off a neat trick by giving you a companion throughout most of the game who doesn’t get on your nerves, doesn’t get in the way and actually helps you out. Elizabeth, the girl you were sent to get, is an ace at picking locks and she scrounges around during fights, throwing you health and ammo when you need it most. She also can rip tears in reality (long story) and pull, for instance, an automated gun into the fray, to fight for you. Elizabeth looks very much like a Disney princess, but there is a darkness to her, as you will come to find out. She is a strong female character, by game standards, though she remains the damsel in distress and leaves it up to you to take the lead when a fight breaks out. Flipping genders, a guy playing the same role would have seemed like a weakling. But she is likeable and complex (oh boy, is she ever complex) and the fact that you are not a silent protagonist but are actually having conversations with her, really helps to get you invested in the story and the characters. My favorite characters; the enigmatic duo you keep running into from time to time, who speak in riddles, know better than you what’s going on, and who seem to be channeling Emma Peel and John Steed from The Avengers.

The trademark of the BioShock series is the ability to use substances (called ‘Vigors’ here) that give you special powers and to combine these with regular weapons. Some of the powers are not especially novel, like the ability to attack with lava or electricity, while others make you wonder about the mental state of the game developers. The first BioShock, for instance, allowed you to unleash a swarm of bees from your hand to attack your foes. This time around, crows will peck people to death for you and if you wear the right piece of clothing, the bodies of those fallen to them can turn into a trap and spring an equally horrid demise on whichever enemy passes by. Because clothing – found in gift-wrapped parcels, often as a reward or just slightly off the main path – also gifts powers or adds an extra dimension to those you already have. There is no apparent in-story logic to any of this. Why wearing a specific hat would give you a 70% chance of setting an enemy on fire if you punch him, is not explained. Why your character is apparently the only one using these Vigors and this kind of gear also remains a mystery. There are vending machines all over the place that sell Vigors and upgrades, but no one seems to have ever bought them, apart from you. You do occasionally run into super-powered enemies, but these aren’t getting their power from Vigors, relying on technology instead. In the end, you won’t care about how silly it all is, because you’ll be too busy having violent, cathartic fun.

By skillfully combining the effects of gear and various Vigors, you can become very powerful indeed, clearing out an entire room in seconds. There is a feeling of overkill to some of the gear. I stumbled onto a very powerful combination early on and disregarded almost all of the stuff I found later, because it couldn’t compete with what I already had.

Burial At Sea - Parte 1
Como si a Irrational y a 2K no les hubiese alcanzado con lanzar uno de los mejores juegos del año, BioShock Infinite, decidieron lanzar el mismo año un DLC que prometía devolver al juego al mundo submarino de sus versiones anteriores: Burrial At Sea Part I, con una historia completamente nueva con los mismos protagonistas del juego principal.

 
En este punto les recomiendo a todos aquellos que no hayan terminado el BioShock Infnite que dejen de leer, ya que es necesario meterse con algunos detalles del final de la historia para poder hablar de este DLC....si deciden seguir leyendo, no los quiero escuchar quejándose.
La historia empieza con Booker DeWitt en su despacho. Booker está perturbado por haber perdido nuevamente a un ser amado: primero su hija Anna, a quien ya conocemos por los sucesos de BioShock Infinite, y luego de Sally, una huérfana a quien adoptó. Una versión adulta de Elizabeth irrumpe en la oficina de Booker ofreciéndole un trabajo...y casualmente se trata de encontrar a Sally.

La historia comienza a cobrar vértigo inmediatamente, dejando poco lugar a una introducción que realmente nos sitúe en el contexto inicial. Rápidamente nos encontraremos cara a cara con uno de los grandes antagonistas de Rapture: el artista psicópata Sander Cohen. Tendremos también un vistazo de Rapture en su esplendor, aunque lamentablemente este sea muy corto.

La gran mayoría del juego, y donde ocurre toda la acción, se desarrolla en un sector abandonado y aislado de Rapture, muy similar a los juegos originales, en donde abundan los splicers. Aquí se mezclan algunas de las mecánicas de los diferentes BioShocks: lugares muy cerrados y recursos muy escasos combinados con los ganchos en el aire y las grietas interdimensionales que puede abrir Elizabeth para ayudarnos.

Vale la pena escribir un párrafo aparte sobre la dificultad: si bien no es extremadamente elevada, la gran escases de recursos nos obliga a replantearnos la estrategia si es que queremos sobrevivir: tendremos que aprovechar cada bala y cada mililitro de EVE al máximo. Por otro lado, resulta muy extraño encontrarnos con los ganchos y rieles elevados en un ambiente tan claustrofóbico.

El juego nos llena de interrogantes desde el inicio: ¿Por qué Booker está vivo y en Rapture?¿Por qué Elizabeth está interesada en él luego de haberlo asesinado al final del juego? ¿Qué versión de Elizabeth estamos viendo? Al igual que Infinite, el juego deja mucho lugar a la libre interpretación, por lo cual si bien algunas de esas preguntas serán respondidas, otras quedarán a nuestra libre interpretación... o por lo menos a ser respondidas en la segunda parte del DLC.

Merece una mención especial el hecho de que absolutamente todo el contenido del juego fue creado especialmente para este DLC, lo cual significa que no se reutilizó absolutamente ningún recurso de BioShock Infinite: texturas, personajes, escenarios, diálogos, sonidos...todo es nuevo. Eso también implica una descarga bastante significativa: 5 GB de datos.

Todos nos emocionamos cuando nos enteramos que íbamos a poder volver a Rapture y poder apreciarla en todo su esplendor. Sin embargo, la experiencia final nos dejó con un sabor agridulce: si bien el DLC nos deja muy atrapados con el final y tiene un par de momentos memorables a lo largo del mismo, termina resultando extremadamente corto y no logra mantener el mismo nivel de narrativa que tiene Infinite. No nos queda más que esperar a ver qué sucede en la Parte 2.

There is nothing to bitch about. The attention and care put into this game can be felt in every little detail. From the graphics to the combat dynamics, enemy types, the interesting characters and top-notch voice acting this game is nearly perfect. Especially the great layouts of the more strategical combat zones deserve praise while the skyhook hopping even brings an awesome and really fun new idea into the genre. If you want a game that delivers for your money, Bioshock Infinite it is.

Bioshock Infinite's core shooting mechanics are standard, the elemental powers don't do a whole lot to spice up the combat and the word can sometimes feel like a series of levels rather than a living breathing place.  That said, all of the strengths this game has to offer more than makes up for it's faults.

Whether it's the impressive visuals and sound, the human interaction with the AI Elizabeth, it's statement on a variety of political and religious issues, or it's story that will grip you emotionally and tantalize you mentally, you get more than your money's worth here.

8.5/10

I wouldn't call this game bad, but it is painfully average. When held in comparison to the previous Shock games, it's been trimmed, narrowed AND watered down. Weapon hoarding is dropped in favor of the CoD-style swapping system, giving you much less attachment to your guns while also making feel much less unique overall. Enemies are mostly humans and encounters are solely restricted to the big, cover-littered arenas the game pushes you along to, secluding combat from the finely constructed (albeit linear) game world. One major point people mark in this game's favor is its story, but that's not much to brag about either. It's 'mature' but that doesn't make it outstanding, just a step above the average video game plot. Of course there's a plot twist that throws you off, but since everyone who played the game knew to expect it, its impact wasn't anywhere near the effect of the twist from the first BioShock.

I'd give this game a rent at least. If you liked it, that's great, but for me it was more of a one-time playthrough. Something you gain a little joy from at the time then forget about and move on as soon as you're done with it.

After the mediocre Bioshock 2, I wasn't sure if this game could live up to the hype over the last 4 years. I started to gain hope for this game after I heard they were focusing only on the single player campaign and completely ignoring multiplayer. When I found out the original story creator was working on the game again (Wasn't around for the second game and it showed), I knew it would be a day one purchase.

Bring us the girl and wipe away the debt. Words that fuel your exploration into the world of Columbia. When you are first thrown into the world via the lighthouse you would expect to start fighting right away like most shooters. This is where the game is unlike others and completely threw me off the normal pacing I'm used to. You are welcomed into the city and able to explore a pretty big area getting a grasp what this world is like compared to the bottom.

Right away you can tell the type of atmosphere these people live in and what type of propaganda Comstock has fed them. I was really surprised the lengths they went to and the risks they took to portray the lengths people will go to for a "perfect society" for themselves. Even all the audio logs you can find randomly around are really interesting and tells you the whole overarching story and the consequences of some actions that have been taken along the way.

The best story motivator is Elizabeth. This the best companion I have had in any video I've played. The way she grows up along the way and her reaction to the events that have impacts to the story is huge feat of storytelling. If you spend the time allowing her to explore (IF you run ahead she will follow you instead of exploring), the time spent to her dialogue and first exposure outside of her room is so wonderfully created that it wowed me throughout the game. The story has a great ending and it doesn't leave on a cliffhanger or anything that seems like it was cut out for the DLC season pass.

No matter which version you choose to play, the world looks amazing and actually outshines the immersible rapture. When you first see the city from the sky its a breath taking sight and really sets the tone they are trying to set. The houses, towns, balloon platforms, people, and even the random trash lying around has detail added to them and is really nice to see. The game still has that look of bioshock on top of it as well, Like the weapons, Vigors (plasmids in Bio 1) and pretty much everything else has that bioshock polish added to them.

The facial animations on the people really surprised me on this one, Especially Elizabeth. You can tell what they are feeling and be able to understand their pain, happiness or whatever they are feeling at the time. Speaking of Elizabeth, her character design and animations she pulls off are wonderfully crafted and really pulls you into the type of character she is.
Even though this takes place on a giant sky city, the level design keeps you on your toes with different areas as you progress through the game. While there is some minor backtracking, there are changes enough to the point it doesn't really have you feeling like your wasting time going back and forth.

The combat focuses on two weapons that you can switch out at any time and the mixtures with them and the vigors makes combat less of a chore and more of a fun experiment on how to completely destroy your enemies in crazy ways. Like for example you can throw an enemy into the air with Bucking Bronco, push him away with Undertow into an electric trap, while shooting at them the entire time. Only a few time the enemies get annoying but it never really bothered me, just slowed down my progress.

This is I feel, will be the best game of 2013. The game has such an amazing story if you pay attention and find all the audio tapes. It merges itself seamlessly with the franchise and the ending makes it feel like a total conclusion on what has happened in the Infinite saga.

Buy, Sale or Pass:
Buy it, than buy the season pass since the game is amazing.

Columbia makes an astonishing first impression, as the floating city setting of Irrational's Bioshock Infinite, built off the wonder and exceptionalism of 1912 America. Everything seemed possible thanks to industrialization. Almost immediately things sour, as the player is confronted with a deconstructed look at Columbia's hidden underclass, and astonishing racism.
Citizens of Columbia pay tribute to their leader, Zachary Comstock, a religious fanatic who believes himself to be a prophet. These prophecies set the game into motion, as Private Dick Booker Dewitt is drawn to Columbia in search of a girl. He is singled out from a crowd, launching Booker into self-defense that will carry him through extreme violence.
The first hour can be spent enjoying the sights and sounds of a place that could not exist. One sequence takes the player through a carnival with playable games, others include a boardwalk with merry-go-round, and a beautiful beach. By contrast, another level is a horrifying museum. The art style is bright and energetic with bold character designs. Irrational's world-building is perfect, including compelling in-game ads, soundscape, and placing a player in the historical moment.The story is anything but light, taking classicism head on, as well as themes of violence and quantum destiny. Conversations help fill in the backstory as do voxophone and kinetescopes.
Booker's first weapon is the skyhook, a gruesome melee weapon. Once you meet Elizabeth, a powerful and highly intelligent, yet innocent woman, she reacts to the player's violent actions. Elizabeth is integral, taking care of herself as well as throwing useful items to Booker. She has the latent ability to open and manipulate tears in space and time to pull in objects from other dimensions. Booker is equipped with turn of the century gun archetypes (revolver, shotgun, etc.) and Vigors, the Columbia version of Plasmids. Gear is also invaluable: it can have offensive and defensive attributes.
Vigors include a fire grenade, crow attacks, the bucking bronco, and others, that can all be combined in amusing and creative ways pertaining to the elements and physics. The effect of Vigors on enemies can often be realistic and graphically violent. Prepare for head pops and bloody skeletons galore.
Weapon upgrades can be readily purchased this time around. Much of the hacking type gameplay has been turned into button presses, with the possession vigor used to take over turrets and automatons. 
Automatons modeled after Presidents are the largest threat to Booker, rivaled only by the Big Daddyesque Handyman, a lumbering behemoth of a mechanical man. Truthfully none of these opponents is too challenging one-on-one. It is only due to some excellent enemy scripting that combat comes alive. 
On the hard difficulty groups teams engage in realistic fashions, rushing the player and forcing precise on the moment decision making. Skyrail combat introduces a whole new element to combat, and feels like a gameplay breath of fresh air. Irrational has crafted vertical arenas in which players can leap amongst opponents, transitioning to upper or lower levels. Bioshock blows the roof off standard shooter design.
Inifinte is perfectly paced, and extremely compelling, better experienced than told, with astonishing developments and interesting characters. At its heart it is a love story, with Booker and Elizabeth linked and compelling protagonists. Side characters like the Lutece twins add shading to the narrative.
Bioshock Infinite could never be the game Bioshock was. But like that title, it is a beautiful and moving game about legacies, fathers and daughters, idealized authoritarian societies fallen into chaos, and many thoughtful, well-considered gameplay elements. As class warfare begins to rip Columbia apart, the player can feel certain that this is due both to Booker's action and his inaction. It is a fine title, and although it clearly positions itself for a sequel, could series director Ken Levine truly have places to take Bioshock, beyond Infinite?

Bioshock Infinite offers great visuals, interesting storyline and strong characters. Especially the two last points are a rare thing, as too many games just concentrate on the first one. Especially Elizabeth is one of the best characters in a game i ever encountered. She has emotions, she has weaknesses and she has a goal. Strangly how she turns from the "girl to be saved" into the mistery that drives her rescuer. Let's say that i seldom felt so many emotions while playing a computer game. What makes the game really special are the many questions that are raised. Slavery, racism and fanatism, both religiuos and political, are the prominent themes. Behind them is - and to say more would be an unforgivable spoiler - the question of action and consequences. Many discussed the end in terms of technology and logic. I think the story and its ending is to be viewed from a philosophical point of view. While playing the game I knew that this is one of the best games. When presented with the last 25 or so minutes of it and the solution, I realized that Bioshock Infinite is a true gem.

INTRO

Burial at Sea is the first part of Bioshock Infinites DLC series and has you playing as Booker Dewitt back down below in Rapture (nostalgia trip). The DLC begins with a young woman requesting you investigate in the case of missing young girl. After a brief conversation the young woman is revealed to be Elizabeth from Infinite’s storyline.

GAMEPLAY

The gameplay hasn’t changed much from the main game so there’s not a lot to talk about really, but there have been a few minor changes to the difficulty that enhance the experience and give you the horror nostalgia trip back to the first Bioshock. First off, ammo is scarce, at first it may seem quite a cheap choice to create difficulty but once you get into it you find yourself using your plastids (yes plastids – IMPORTANT) more than you would have in Infinite. I’m unsure about anyone else but in Infinite’s storyline I found myself using Vigours/Plastids to enhance my gun play (Bucking Bronco TO shotgun) rather than using them for their own powers. Next we have the weapon wheel, YES it’s back! Yay! Unfortunately you are still restricted to two weapons at once as using the weapon wheel will only switch out the weapon you are holding but it’s still infinitely (no pun intended) better than Infinite’s system. Although not every gameplay aspect has been reviewed, unfortunately the stealth gameplay still suffers from serious bugs or just flat out not working at all.

 
//

*SPOILER WARNING*

//

 
STORY

Now, as was the same with Infinite (I felt anyway) the gameplay was the basic rather mundane aspect of the game as I found the gameplay sections boring and simple gateways between the storyline. Once again this is the case. The story is still phenomenal with an awesome ending that leaves us with a cliff-hanger but not SO much that it seems annoying. Without spoiling any surprises the story finishes as you would expect, if you pay attention to what Elizabeth is saying throughout the DLC (and if you actually played Infinite), with a huge reveal and explanation simultaneously, leading into what the next DLC will play as. BUT, as epic as the story was I feel it had some issues. The storyline in DLC (I find) tends to be SIDE stories or what COULD have happened, but this doesn’t feel like that, this feels like it’s actually part of the main story as it is continuing that story. I am firmly against an extension to a storyline that we already paid for; this DLC opened up what we knew would happen and is asking for more money – bad developers. BAD. Also, another bad developer move, why did you give a blurb for episode two? The blurb for episode 2 gives SERIOUS hints of the ending of this DLC.

CONCLUSION

While I agree that the original storyline shouldn’t be continued in paid DLC or not, I can’t deny how epic this DLC was. Again, I personally feel the gameplay sections in Infinite and it’s DLC were simple filler sections to get me back into the epic story, but I would defiantly say the gameplay sections were less mundane than that of Infinite (maybe nostalgia me talking but hey). So here it is, the killer question; is it worth it? No. I wouldn’t say so, it’s fun and all, but if you can get the same experience watching someone play a game, then it’s not worth it in my opinion. Like I said the gameplay sections still felt like filler so simply watching the cut scenes/conversations over someone’s shoulder would be enough to get what was great about this – the story. Whenever I’m thinking about buying DLC I look back at some of my all the time favourite – Dragonborn. Lots to do, new items, NOT a continued story but a side story and a great side story as well. Now considering you can get Dragonborn for two pounds more, you wouldn’t expect such a HUGE difference in quality – but unfortunately there is.

This is very much a redo of the first Bioshock game.  The story is twisted the same, and the gameplay is more or less the same as well.  Think of it as Bioshock with a new face!  There are new interactions, such as the skyline, although fun, difficult to master the "ride and shoot" method.  I bought into this game because of the hype, but after playing and beating it, I don't quite get the huge roar of the crowd it got.  Is it fun?  Yes!  But the restrictions of the weapon selection and powers annoy me.  I'd like to choose to use any weapons I'd like to, not be limited to what I can buy or find.  If you liked Bioshock and you like first person shooters, this is your game!  Some of the later parts of the game are slightly annoying when you feel like you are doing the same thing over again, but I digress.  I don't know for me that I'll ever do another play through, but I'll definitely be checking out the DLC.

С момента анонса этой игры, мои друзья уговаривали меня пройти ее. Я отказывался, аргументируя это, в основном, нелепыми доводами. 
	Шло время. В ажиотаже "Summer Sale" игра была куплена и отложена в дальний ящик. И вот, где-то через пол года, я все же взялся за нее. Все волнения масмедиа вокруг этой игры если не утихли, то явно умерили свой пыл. На этот шедевр у меня ушло порядка 12 часов. 12 часов прогулки по утопической Америке начала ХХ века. Эта игра завораживает 4мя вещами: 
	1) Скрупулезным вниманием к деталям и мелочам. 
	2) Главной героиней, чьи мимика и жесты делают ее самым экспрессивным и открытым персонажем, которого я когда либо встречал. Вообще, сама концепция "хрупкая милая девушка, наделенная великой силой" многим приходится по душе. Не знаю с чем это связано, но чую, что одному австрийскому психологу стоит передать привет. 
	3) Третий пункт, это озвучка. Трой и Кортни, вы великолепны. Я даже рад, что в игре так мало музыки, которая бы хоть как-то приглушала их голоса.
	4) И напоследок - сюжет. Все 12 часов я играл лишь для того, чтобы послушать и понаблюдать за Элизабет. "Сюжет? А он есть? Да бросьте! Финал будет банален, мне уже частично его проспойлерили" Так я думал до самой финальной сцены, ставшей ножом в спину. Фанаты Heavy Rain поймут, о чем я. Это нужно увидеть и прочувствовать. 
	Игра заслуживает 10 из 10и по всем пунктам. Это шедевр с десятками вопросов и без единого ответа. Я искренне надеюсь, что в продолжении нам расскажут всю историю без пробелов и умалчивания.
	Я жалею лишь о том, что пропустил всеобщую обсуждаемость. Не с кем было поделиться душевными переживаниями и эмоциями. Ужасно жалею о подобном промахе...

The base game is fantastic - great visuals, good gameplay, and intriguing story.
What it isn't is "Bioshock" - literally. Even ignoring the juxtaposition of Raptures tight halls to Columbia's open spaces - it doesn't follow any of the original themes or focal narrative points to make it in keeping with that series - for instance plasmids are eschewed in favour of Vigors, but while plasmids were fundamental to the world of Rapture, vigors are just kinda... there. And underutilised! Only Booker seems to use them, compared to the hoards of splicers in Rapture.
Bioshock should be about biology and organisms - literally in the form of plasmids, but also socially, memetically. 
Infinite doesn't have that. It's also less focussed on survival and resource management, instead more focussed on individual battles. This definitely helps the difficulty curve, but it does remove some of the long-term versus short-term cost-benefit weighing that the first 2 games had.

Don't get me wrong, Infinite is great, but it isn't Bioshock - more "Quantum shock" - so adjust your expectations.
